data.description: The Appalachian Trail is a 2,190+ mile long public footpath that traverses the scenic, wooded, pastoral, wild, and culturally resonant lands of the Appalachian Mountains. Conceived in 1921, built by private citizens, and completed in 1937, today the trail is managed by the National Park Service, US Forest Service, Appalachian Trail Conservancy, numerous state agencies and thousands of volunteers.
data.directionsInfo: There are many points of access along the Appalachian Trail, whether it is by car, train, bus or plane. For more detailed directions, please refer to the "Directions" section of our park webpage.

operatingHours.description:
In general, the Appalachian Trail is open year-round. The northern terminus at Mount Katahdin in Maine is within Baxter State Park, which may be closed in winter months, depending on weather conditions. 
Particular sections of the Trail, and less-developed roads accessing the Trail, may be closed temporarily for a number of reasons, but otherwise the trail is open.
operatingHours.name: Appalachian National Scenic Trail

images.title: McAfee Knob
images.altText: Silhouette of a man with backpack standing on McAfee Knob at sunset with mountains in the distance.
images.caption: McAfee Knob is one of the most popular locations along the A.T. to take photographs.

images.title: Appalachian Trail
images.altText: The Appalachian Trail runs across a mountain ridge line with views to the horizon of mountain range.
images.caption: Crossing into thirteen states, hikers experience a variety of scenery along the way.

images.title: The Infamous White Blaze of the A.T.
images.altText: A white blaze marks a tree in the foreground, with a man and child walking away on the wooded trail.
images.caption: The white blaze marks the Appalachian Trail as a way for hikers to identify the route.

images.credit: Photo Credit: Maine Appalachian Trail Club
images.title: Volunteer on the A.T.
images.altText: A volunteer is carrying a split log while walking across a wooden footbridge in the woods.
images.caption: The Appalachian Trail is maintained largely by volunteers.

images.title: Winter on the A.T.
images.altText: A snowy winter view from the A.T. overlooking snowy mountains and clouds in the distance.
images.caption: Hikers can experience many seasons along the A.T. all year round. It is important to be prepared.

data.weatherInfo: It is your responsibility to be prepared for all weather conditions, including extreme and unexpected weather changes year-round. As the trail runs from Georgia to Maine there will be different weather conditions depending on your location. For weather along specific sections of the trail and at specific shelters, please refer to: http://www.atweather.org/
data.name: Appalachian

data.fullName: Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area
data.description: Situated within the most densely populated region of the United States, Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area provides a unique opportunity to experience tranquil landscapes, rich human history, and striking scenery along 40 miles of the longest free-flowing river east of the Mississippi. The park offers year-round recreation including hiking, paddling, fishing, and hunting.

emailAddresses.description: Please use this email address for any park related questions. We will forward your information to the appropriate park representative that can answer your questions or address your concerns. We look forward to hearing from you.

entranceFees.description: Entrance fee for beaches and boat launches. Fee is good for one vehicle and it's passengers (up to 7 people).
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle

entrancePasses.description:
Annual seasonal pass for expanded amenity fee areas.

Passes can be purchased from park visitor centers or staffed fee booths located at Milford Beach, Smithfield Beach, and Turtle Beach.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

data.directionsInfo: Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area is a long, narrow park that sits between two major interstates, I-80 at the south and I-84 at the north. US 209 is the main north/south road through the park on the Pennsylvania side and Old Mine Road is the main north/south road though the park on the New Jersey side.

operatingHours.description: Park roads are open 24-hours a day. Most day-use areas within the park are open sunrise to sunset (such as trailhead parking lots, Millbrook Village, and all picnic areas).
operatingHours.name: Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area

addresses.line1: Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area

images.title: Delaware Water Gap
images.altText: View of the Delaware River cutting between two low mountain peaks
images.caption: The Delaware Water Gap is the geologic formation that gives the park its name. This distinctive cut thru the Kittatinny ridgeline was made by the Delaware River over thousands of years.

images.title: Fulmer Falls
images.altText: A waterfall flows toward the viewer along a rocky riverbed.
images.caption: Fulmer Falls is the second of three waterfalls in George W. Childs Park

images.title: Millbrook Days
images.altText: A woman braids rye straw for hatmaking
images.caption: A woman braids rye straw for hatmaking

images.title: River View from Mount Tammany
images.altText: a snaking river view from a mountain top
images.caption: High view of the Delaware River from atop Mount Tammany

images.title: Nesting Great Blue Herons
images.altText: Great Blue Herons attending their nests in a tree
images.caption: Great Blue Herons attend their nests in a tree

images.title: Dingmans Falls
images.altText: A strongly running Dingmans Falls waterfall surrounded by plants.
images.caption: Dingmans Falls in summer, as seen from the wheelchair and stroller accessible boardwalk

images.title: Silver Thread Falls
images.altText: Tall and narrow, Silver Thread Falls
images.caption: Silver Thread Falls, as seen from the Dingmans Falls Boardwalk

data.weatherInfo: Spring: Temperatures usually range from lows of 26 F to highs of 80 F with average rainfall of 5 inches. Summer: Temperatures usually range from lows of 55 F to highs of 85 F with average rainfall of 4 inches. Fall: Temperatures usually range from lows of 30 F to highs of 83F. Fall foliage is at its peak sometime in October as daily mountain temperatures vary frequently and influence the change. Winter: Temperatures usually range from lows of 15 F to highs of 49 F.
data.name: Delaware Water Gap

data.fullName: Ellis Island Part of Statue of Liberty National Monument
data.description: Millions of Americans and people around the world have ancestors who came through Ellis Island. The Main Immigration Building was the epicenter of one of the greatest migrations in modern history. Today, Ellis Island is a memorial to all who pursued the American dream and have made this nation their adopted home.
data.directionsInfo: Ellis Island is located in New York Harbor and can only be reached by ferry. Ferries are operated by Statue City Cruises and depart from The Battery in New York City or from Liberty State Park in Jersey City, NJ.

operatingHours.description:
Access to Liberty and Ellis Islands is by Statue City Cruises ferry only. For ferry departure times and ticketing information visit http://www.statuecitycruises.com or call 1-877-LADY-TIX. 

The last entrance into the statue is at 4:00 PM.
operatingHours.name: Park Hours

addresses.line1: Ellis Island National Museum of Immigration

images.title: Ellis Island Museum of Immigration
images.altText: Beaux-Arts brick and limestone building with large arched windows and cupola-topped towers.
images.caption: Over 12 million immigrants were processed at Ellis Island during the peak years of 1892-1924, most through this building which opened in 1900.

images.title: Ellis Island's Registry Room
images.altText: Great Hall has terra cotta-colored tile floor, a balcony, large arched windows, and vaulted ceiling
images.caption: The Registry Room, also known as the Great Hall, is where millions of immigrants were inspected. They were required to pass both a medical and legal inspection before being allowed to enter the United States.

images.title: Ellis Island Museum of Immigration
images.altText: Brick and limestone building with maroon canopy leading to entrance.
images.caption: Visitors to the museum today arrive by ferry, just like immigrants did a century ago.

images.title: Replica Inspection Desk in the Registry Room
images.altText: Honey oak colored tall desk on tiled floor in Great Hall with arched windows and vaulted ceiling.
images.caption: Inspectors at Ellis Island would conduct the legal examination from behind desks like these a century ago.

images.title: Bird's Eye View of Ellis Island
images.altText: Artificially-expanded largely rectangular island with straight seawalls and large buildings.
images.caption: Ellis Island was expanded from just a couple acres to over 30 to make room for a large immigration processing station, that included a state of the art hospital complex.

data.weatherInfo: It is typically colder and more windy in New York Harbor than elsewhere in New York City. Winters are cold and damp. Spring and Fall can range from chilly to warm. Summers are warm to hot and humid.
data.name: Ellis Island
data.designation: Part of Statue of Liberty National Monument

data.description: Spanning 27,000 acres from Sandy Hook in New Jersey to Breezy Point in New York City, the park is both the gateway from the ocean into New York Harbor, and the gateway to the National Park Service for millions of visitors every year. Gateway offers green spaces and beaches alongside historic structures and cultural landscapes. Every day, Gateway is open for you to explore, envision, and enjoy!
data.directionsInfo: Gateway is located in two states; NJ and NY, and has three units: Jamaica Bay, Sandy Hook and Staten Island. You can access most of our park by car and public transportation. Please visit our website for specific directions to all of our units

operatingHours.description: Includes Bergen Beach, Floyd Bennett Field, Fort Tilden, Frank Charles Park, Hamilton Beach, Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge, Canarsie Pier, Jacob Riis Park, North Channel Bridge, Plumb Beach and Spring Creek.
operatingHours.name: Jamaica Bay Unit  hours

operatingHours.description: Sandy Hook is open from 6 am to 9 pm.
operatingHours.name: Sandy Hook hours

operatingHours.description: The Staten Island unit includes Fort Wadsworth, Great Kills and Miller Field. The park is open from 6 am to 9 pm.
operatingHours.name: Staten Island hours

images.title: You can camp at all three units of Gateway
images.altText: Tent at  Floyd Bennett Field campsite in Gateway's Jamaica Bay unit.
images.caption: You can camp at all three units of Gateway, in the shadow of NYC.

images.title: Enjoying a summer's day at Jacob Riis Park
images.altText: Visitors enjoying the sun and sand at Jacob Riis Park
images.caption: Millions of visitors visit Gateway's beaches every summer.

images.title: Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge
images.altText: The Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge Visitor Center
images.caption: The Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge is the only wildlife refuge in the National Park Service

images.title: The Sandy Hook Lighthouse
images.altText: The Sandy Hook lighthouse and keepers quarters
images.caption: The Sandy Hook Lighthouse is the oldest continuously operating lighthouse in the United States.

images.title: Battery Weed
images.altText: Battery Weed is the fort under the Verrazano Narrows Bridge in Staten Island.
images.caption: Battery Weeds guards the entrance to the New York harbor.

data.weatherInfo: Gateway National Recreation Area includes several separate land areas spread throughout the New York metropolitan area. The New York area experiences four distinct seasons. Temperatures are moderate in the spring and fall, but range from the high 90's during the summer to snow and sleet in winter.
data.name: Gateway

data.description: Both the harbor and river were named for the shorebird and waterfowl eggs covering their meadows. During the American Revolution, privateers hid here. Established as a National Park Service site in 1992, Great Egg Harbor National Wild and Scenic River is one of nation's best birding spots. Local jurisdictions administer its lands. The 129-mile river system flows through Pinelands National Reserve.

emailAddresses.description: Links to Atlantic County Parks Program Coordinator Lambert Nicole (not an NPS employee). They send out brochures, etc.

data.directionsInfo: Estell Manor Park, where visitors can see the Great Egg Harbor National Scenic and Recreational River, is located 3.5 miles South of Mays Landing, New Jersey, off of Route 50. It is approximately 17 miles west of Atlantic City. There is a stamper for Passport Stamp Books at the Fox Nature Center, and a stamp can be obtained at the mailing address provided below.

operatingHours.description: The Great Egg Harbor River is a 55.0-mile-long (88.5 km) river in southern New Jersey in the United States. It is one of the major rivers that traverse the largely pristine Pinelands, draining 308 square miles (800 km2) of wetlands into the Atlantic Ocean at Great Egg Harbor, from which it takes its name. At river location in Estell Manor Park - please check (609) 625-1897 for hours.
operatingHours.name: Great Egg Harbor River Hours

addresses.line1: Great Egg Harbor National Scenic and Recreational River
addresses.line2: c/o National Park Service Northeast Region Office

data.fullName: Lower Delaware National Wild and Scenic River
data.description: The Delaware River, the largest free-flowing river in the eastern United States, runs past forests, farmlands and villages. It also links some of the most densely populated regions in America. In 2000, the National Wild and Scenic River System incorporated key segments of the lower Delaware River to form this unit of the National Park System.
data.directionsInfo: The Lower Delaware National Wild and Scenic River is located between Interstate 80 (at Portland, Pennsylvania and Columbia, New Jersey) and Interstate 95 (at exit 51 in Washington Crossing, Pennsylvania and exit 1 in Washington Crossing, New Jersey). In Pennsylvania, follow PA-611 and PA-32 to drive along the river. In New Jersey, follow NJ-29 south of Frenchtown for a drive along the river.

operatingHours.description: The largest free-flowing river in the eastern United States, the Delaware River runs past forests, farmlands, and villages, and it also links some of the most densely populated regions in America. In 2000, the National Wild and Scenic River System incorporated key segments of the lower Delaware River to form this unit of the National Park System.
operatingHours.name: Lower Delaware National Wild and Scenic River

data.description: Morristown National Historical Park commemorates the sites of General Washington and the Continental Armys winter encampment from December 1779 to June 1780, where soldiers survived the coldest winter on record. The park also maintains a museum and library collection related to the encampments and to George Washington, as well as items from both pre- and post-Revolutionary America.
data.directionsInfo: Morristown National Historical Park is easiest to see by car. There are four different sites throughout the greater Morristown area. Washington's Headquarters Museum / Ford Mansion and Fort Nonsense are located in Morristown. The Jockey Hollow unit with its visitor center and historic Wick House; and the New Jersey Brigade Area are both about 6 miles south of Morristown, Detailed directions can be found on the park website.

exceptions.name: Federal Holiday February 17, 2025 - Washington's Headquarters bulidings open

operatingHours.description:
Washington's Headquarters Museum: Open Thursday-Sunday 10:00 AM to 4:00 PM.
Jockey Hollow Visitor Center: Open Thursday-Sunday 10:00 AM to 4:00 PM.
operatingHours.name: Headquarters Museum and Jockey Hollow Visitor Center.

operatingHours.description:
Current Grounds Hours: 8:00 AM to 8:00 PM
In Morristown, the open grounds hours from Washington's Headquarters/Ford Mansion and Fort Nonsense, the Jockey Hollow, and the New Jersey Brigade units change according to the seasons. Please follow the Active Exceptions listed, as they are the current hours. Unplanned closures or delayed openings may occur for snow and ice or tree removal or road construction and repair. Check the website or facebook.com/MorristownNPS for current information.
operatingHours.name: Park Grounds

images.caption: The front facade of the Washington's Headquarters Museum, which was designed in 1933 to look similar to Washington's Mt Vernon home.

images.caption: These replica soldier huts represent the location of the Pennsylvania Brigade encampment site in Jockey Hollow

images.title: Cross Estate Mansion and Gardens
images.altText: The Cross Estate mansion in the springtime
images.caption: The Cross Estate property was the site of the New Jersey Brigade winter encampement in 1779-1780. Today the encampment site is preserved while the estate is host to several beautiful gardens.

images.caption: The Ford Mansion where General Washington headquartered during the winter of 1779-80

images.title: View from Fort Nonsense

images.caption: Fort Nonsense--the site of an earthen fort during the American Revolution-offers a view toward New York City

images.altText: A white colonial building with snow in the foreground and a blue sky and trees in the background
images.caption: The Ford Mansion was the headquarters for General George Washington during the "Hard Winter" of 1779-1780

data.weatherInfo: Weather in this part of New Jersey is typical of the mid-Atlantic region--a humid continental climate with hot, humid summers and moderately cold winters.
data.name: Morristown

data.description: This is truly a special place. It's classified as a United States Biosphere Reserve and in 1978 was established by Congress as the countrys first National Reserve. It includes portions of seven southern New Jersey counties, and encompasses over one-million acres of farms, forests and wetlands. It contains 56 communities, from hamlets to suburbs, with over 700,000 permanent residents.
data.directionsInfo: The Pinelands National Reserve includes portions of seven southern New Jersey counties, and encompasses over one-million acres of farms, forests and wetlands. It contains 56 communities, from hamlets to suburbs, with over 700,000 permanent residents.

operatingHours.description: The Pinelands National Reserve stretches across portions of seven counties in southern New Jersey, covering about 22% of the state. The area is comprised of both public and private lands. Public lands include parks, forests, wildlife refuges, and military bases. Private lands include 56 communities that range in size from small from villages to large towns. More than 700,000 permanent residents live the Pinelands National Reserve. The public lands are open 24 hours.
operatingHours.name: Pinelands Hours

images.title: Batona Trail in the NJ Pinelands
images.altText: Tall pine trees surround a thin unpaved trail
images.caption: Batona Trail in the Brendan T. Byrne State Forest part of the NJ Pinelands

data.weatherInfo: Spring: 50-70F, sunny with some rain Summer: 70-90F, mostly sunny with some rain Winter: 0-35F, snow is common Fall: 50-70F
data.name: New Jersey Pinelands

data.fullName: Paterson Great Falls National Historical Park
data.description: Silk cloth and steam locomotives; textiles and continuous paper rolls; firearms and aircraft engines. What do these things have in common? All were manufactured in the same place - Paterson, NJ. In 1792, Paterson was established as America's first planned industrial city, centered around the Great Falls of the Passaic River. From humble mills rose industries that changed the face of the nation.
data.directionsInfo: From: Garden State Parkway (New Jersey) North: Take exit 155P on left to Route 19 TO WEST Route 80 Paterson. South: Take Exit 159 (Saddlebrook) on your right. After taking the exit, make your second right onto I-80 West (Paterson). From: Interstate 80 I-80 West: Take Exit 57 A-B. Taking (Exit 57- B) (Downtown Paterson) follow the Downtown Paterson sign. I-80 East: Take (Exit 57- B), take exit Route 80 west Grand St./ Del Water Gap KEEP RIGHT exit. Stay to the right for Grand Street exit ramp.

operatingHours.description:
Grounds are open 7 days a weel and Rangers are available 9:00AM-4:30PM Wednesday-Sunday . Please call 973-523-0370 or 201-458-3475(park cell number) the day of your visit to ensure tour availability. Grounds open suggested time for visiting grounds between sunrise-sunset.
The National Park's main visitor parking lot at 72 McBride Avenue Extension will be closed every day sometime after dark and reopened every morning between 7:45am and 8:45am.
operatingHours.name: General Park Hours

data.description: Today, the brick buildings on Main Street in West Orange, NJ seem quiet, betraying little evidence of the research, development, and innovation of their heyday. Visitors can step back in time to Thomas Edisons home and laboratory, when machines were run by belts and pulleys and music was played on phonographs. Discover where Americas greatest inventor changed our world forever.

emailAddresses.description: Please use this email to send us your questions/concerns.

entranceFees.description: THIS GUIDED WALKING TOUR IS FOR Elementary, Middle, and College Groups to learn about Thomas Edisons West Orange Laboratory as a working invention factory where ideas became products, and those products became industries we all enjoy today.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Education/Academic Groups

entranceFees.description: Children 15 and under free of charge. Visitors may pay the fee on the day of their visit at the visitor center, or may choose to pay it online via Recreation.gov. Visitors to Glenmont and the Edison home must also pay this entrance fee. Credit or debt card payments only.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

entrancePasses.description: Valid ONLY at Thomas Edison National Historical Park for 12 months from the date of purchase. Permits the cardholder and 3 adult guests' entrance (16 years and older, children 15 and younger are free).  Includes Laboratory Complex and Glenmont Estate. All visitors must begin their visit at the Laboratory Complex. Please note: this does not guarantee entry into the mansion at Glenmont.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

data.directionsInfo: From the Garden State Parkway take exit 145 or from the New Jersey Turnpike take Exit 15W to Route 280 West. Take Route 280 West to Exit 10. Turn right onto Northfield Avenue. At second light turn left onto Main Street. Go about 0.75 mile to parking on left and Laboratory Complex on the right. From Route 280 East take exit 9. Turn left onto Mt. Pleasant Avenue. At second traffic light turn left onto Main Street. Go about 0.50 mile to parking on left and Laboratory Complex on the right.

operatingHours.description: All visitors must go to the Laboratory Complex first to obtain their entry pass and Glenmont Grounds pass. (Glenmont is currently only open on Saturday and Sunday)
operatingHours.name: Laboratory Complex

images.title: Glenmont - Home of Thomas Edison
images.altText: Large salmon colored Victorian mansion with green lawn and blue sky
images.caption: Thomas Edison purchased Glenmont as a wedding present for his wife Mina in 1886, for the cost of $125,000 USD.

images.title: Heavy Machine Shop at the Edison Laboratory Complex
images.altText: Large work space room with machines connected to belts and pullies
images.caption: One of main machine shops, where Thomas Edison and his staff worked on research and development, prototypes, and products.

images.title: Glenmont Garage
images.altText: Cream colored, two story cement building surrounded by large trees
images.caption: Thomas Edison's poured concrete garage houses both electric and gas powered vehicles belonging to the Edison family.

images.title: Park Entrance
images.altText: Small red building next to large brick building with a water tower in the background.
images.caption: Just as Thomas Edison did every morning, visitors can walk in his footsteps by entering the laboratory complex's iron main gate.

images.title: Replica Black Maria
images.altText: Large black building covered in tar paper surrounded by a barrier fence
images.caption: The Black Maria was the first building built for the recording of motion pictures. This exact replica of the original was built as a movie set for the film "Edison the Man", starring Spencer Tracy, in 1954.

data.weatherInfo: Spring and Fall weather can be cool, while summer is usually warm and humid. Winter is frequently snowy and cold. It is recommended that visitors dress for the weather. Visitors may need jackets or rain gear as they will be walking between buildings as they tour the park during inclement weather. Please keep any rain gear/umbrellas with you during your visit.
data.name: Thomas Edison

data.fullName: Washington-Rochambeau Revolutionary Route National Historic Trail
data.description: Of the happiness I have enjoyed in our private friendship. The remembrance of which will be one of the most pleasing Circumstances of my life. Comte de Rochambeau on his relationship with George Washington
data.directionsInfo: The Washington-Rochambeau Revolutionary Route National Historic Trail encompasses over 680 miles of land and water trails through Rhode Island, Massachusetts, Connecticut, New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Delaware, Maryland, Washington D.C., and Virginia

operatingHours.description: The Washington-Rochambeau Revolutionary Route NHT can be travelled year-round. The NHT connects national, state, and local parks as well a great number of historic sites and landmarks. Visitors should contact sites or attractions individually as operating hours vary widely by site and season.
operatingHours.name: Washington-Rochamebeau National Historic Trail

addresses.line2: Make requests of Trail Administrator at Johnny_Carawan@NPS.gov

images.title: Washington Rochambeau
images.altText: Flag marking the trail
images.caption: Washington-Rochambeau NHT banner on 2nd Street in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

data.weatherInfo: With over 680 miles of land and water trails and hundreds of historical sites, there is a wide variety in weather. Please check with your favorite weather website before traveling.
data.name: Washington-Rochambeau Revolutionary Route
